conclusion: Need to analyze the given graphs and use the properties of an ideal gas to determine the pressure at 600 K.
Left graph shows a linear relationship between pressure and temperature.
Right graph shows a linear relationship between volume and temperature.
Left graph suggests the process is isobaric (constant pressure) as pressure increases linearly with temperature.
Right graph suggests the process is isobaric as volume increases with temperature, consistent with V ∝ T.
Ideal gas law is PV = nRT, where P is pressure, V is volume, n is number of moles, R is universal gas constant, and T is temperature.
Since the process is isobaric, pressure P is constant and can be determined using graph data.
Pressure at T = 200 K is 0.5 x 10^5 Pa and at T = 400 K is 1.0 x 10^5 Pa from the left graph.
Slope of the line in the p-T graph is 2500 Pa/K.
Pressure at T = 600 K is calculated as 1.05 x 10^6 Pa using the slope.
Volume at T = 400 K is 2.5 m³ and at T = 600 K is 3.0 m³ from the right graph.
Slope of the line in the V-T graph is 0.0025 m³/K.
Using ideal gas law and constant pressure, the ratio of volumes at different temperatures is consistent with the V-T graph slope.
Final pressure of the gas at 600 K is determined to be 1.05 x 10^6 Pa.
